label: q_fi02_q07_temporal
content:
{
  "question_id": "fi02_q07_temporal",
  "scope_id": "financial_irregularity_02",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "temporal",
  "prompt": "When did accounts receivable aging first show deterioration, and how has the 90+ days bucket trended?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "AR aging began deteriorating during the early signal phase as revenue acceleration outpaced collections. The 90+ day bucket grew steadily from a healthy baseline to a significant portion of total receivables over the escalation period.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_010",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_013",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_017",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_025"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "correlation between revenue acceleration and aging-bucket shift rules out organic growth as explanation",
      "structural cash conversion shortfall persists independent of seasonal and volume factors",
      "DSO increased progressively from baseline levels through early signal to escalation, with the rate of deterioration accelerating over successive reporting periods rather than stabilizing"
    ]
  }
}
